attributes.title: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life
attributes.description: In this project, we test the hypothesis that emotional granularity (a measure of the precision of an individual’s emotion concepts) is significantly positively correlated with resting respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA; used as an index of parasympathetic activity and proxy measure of efficient allostasis) as measured in daily life. We further investigate the nature of this relationship by characterizing patterns of cardiovascular activity during resting periods and emotional events, including and in comparison with measures of emotional granularity.

q1.value: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life: Clustering analyses

q2.value: Katie Hoemann, Zulqarnain Khan, Karen Quigley, Lisa Feldman Barrett

q3.value: Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) is an index of parasympathetic nervous system (PNS) activity and of cardiovascular health. Previous research suggests that higher resting RSA values may be associated with greater emotional granularity, yet the exact nature of this relationship has not been explored. Further, it may also be the case that measures of sympathetic nervous system (SNS) activity are (also) predictive of cardiovascular health. Pre-ejection period (PEP, a systolic time interval related to heart contractility) is an inverse index of SNS activity and can be compared against RSA to determine whether PNS or SNS features have a stronger relationship with emotional granularity. In these analyses, we perform unsupervised clustering analyses on peripheral physiological data and emotional self-reports collected in daily life, to describe the relationship between emotional granularity and multiple features of cardiovascular activity.

q4.value:
When clustering is run across participants, results will be driven by estimates of emotional granularity and/or RSA, rather than PEP or other cardiovascular features. That is, participants will cluster together based on similar levels of granularity and/or RSA.
When clustering is run within participants (across days), the number of clusters identified per participant will correlate with granularity, such that more clusters will be discovered for individuals with higher granularity.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
As part of a larger study on affective experience and decision making in daily life, 52 participants completed approximately 14, eight-hour days of ambulatory peripheral physiological monitoring. 

Each day, participants visited the lab and were outfitted with sensors and portable equipment to measure their electrocardiogram (ECG) and impedance cardiogram (ICG) as well as bodily movement and posture (via accelerometers). A custom-built smartphone application initiated an experience sampling prompt any time the interbeat interval (IBI; also called heart period) changed by more than ±167ms over an eight-second period, with these thresholds adjusted per participant to ensure they received a comparable number of prompts per day. Prompts were not generated if participants had moved substantially or shifted posture within the proceeding 30s. At each sampling event, participants were prompted to respond to a series of questions presented in smartphone application, including to freely list and provide intensity ratings for their experienced emotions. 

Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. As part of this survey, participants rated each emotional event on a set of 18 standard emotions.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: To date, only data pertaining to the periods surrounding experience samplings have been analyzed. Peripheral physiological data from periods of seated rest (when no experience sampling prompts were generated) have not yet been pre-processed or analyzed.

question.value:
Sixty-seven participants ranging in age from 18-36 years (55% female; 38.8% White, 3.0% Black, 29.8% Asian, 28.4% other; M = 22.8 years, SD = 4.4 years) were recruited from the greater Boston area through posted advertisements, as well as Northeastern University classrooms and online portals. Eligible participants were non-smoking, fluent English-speakers, and excluded if they had a history of cardiovascular illness or stroke, chronic medical conditions, mental illness, asthma, skin allergies, or very sensitive skin. Eligible participants also confirmed they were not taking any medications known to influence physiological arousal including medications for ADHD, insomnia, anxiety, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, epilepsy/seizures, cold/flu, or fever/allergies. Participants received $490 as compensation for completing all parts of the study, plus up to an additional $55 in compliance and task incentives. 

Of the 67 recruited participants, six withdrew and an additional nine were dismissed due to poor compliance. A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). 

Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling distributed across a three- to four-week period (M = 24.9 days, SD = 5.5 days). On each day of experience sampling, participants came into the lab and were instrumented for peripheral physiological recordings. Participants were instructed to continue physiological recordings for eight hours each day, after which they were able to remove and recharge all equipment. Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. Before and after the two-week experience sampling protocol, participants also completed two in-lab sessions. The data from these in-lab sessions are not relevant to the present analyses.

q13.value: A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling.

question.value:
From the peripheral physiological (ECG and ICG) data, we will isolate periods of seated rest according to the following criteria:
- Participant is included in the final sample
- Data from the given day were not corrupted or (for end of day surveys) reported late
- Participant position is seated and not moving (i.e., no forward acceleration)
- Participant maintains this position for at least 30 seconds
- No experience sampling prompt was generated during the rest period

From these resting periods, we will derive the following measures of cardiovascular activity using 30-s bins:
- Inter-beat interval (IBI; i.e., heart rate [HR], derived from ECG)
- Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA; frequency-based measure of heart rate variability [HRV], derived from ECG)
- Respiration rate (RR; derived from ICG [Z0])
- Pre-ejection period (PEP; time-based measure of heart contractility, inverse index of sympathetic activity, derived from ICG and ECG)
ECG and ICG data will be analyzed following the signal processing pipeline outlined in Hoemann et al (2020, January 14) - see Other section for full citation. IBI, RSA, and PEP will be extracted based on prior literature, as detailed in Hoemann et al (2020, January 14). RR will be derived from ICG (Z0) following Ernst et al (1999).

From the self-reported experience sampling data, we will analyze the intensity endorsements to 18 standard emotion terms from the end-of-day surveys. For each experience sampling prompt, participants rated the following emotions on a 7-point Likert style scale from 0 ('not at all') to 6 ('very much') : “afraid”, “amused”, “angry”, “bored”, “calm”, “disgusted”, “embarrassed”, “excited”, “frustrated”, “grateful”, “happy”, “neutral”, “proud”, “relieved”, “sad”, “serene”, “surprised”, and “worn out”.

For each period seated rest, we will derive the mean across all 30-s bins, such that we have one measure of IBI, RSA, RR, and PEP for each resting period. We will then take the mean and standard deviation across all resting periods for a given participant.

For the experience sampling data, we will derive an index of emotional granularity using intra-class correlations (ICCs) using the 'A-k' method (absolute agreement with averaged raters). We will calculate separate ICCs for ratings of positively-valenced emotion (e.g., happy, calm, grateful) and negatively-valenced emotions (e.g., angry, sad, afraid); we will use the mean of these to represent overall granularity. ICC values will be Fisher transformed and inverted (i.e., multiplied by -1, such that most positive values represent higher granularity). ICCs will be calculated across all data for a given participant.

Analyses will be performed at two levels: participant (across periods of seated rest) and group (across participants). These are separate rather than nested analyses.

Participant-level analysis: We will submit all periods of seated rest from each individual to a separate clustering analysis using Dirichlet Process-Gaussian Mixture Modeling (DP-GMM) with Variational Inference. Data points will be four-dimensional vectors of resting period means for IBI, RSA, RR, and PEP; these will be standardized prior to clustering by subtracting the grand mean and dividing by the standard deviation of each feature. We will examine the number of clusters that result from each idiographic analysis; for purposes of comparison across participants, we will threshold the number of clusters to only include those that accounts for at least 5% of seated rest periods. We will assess the cross-participant correlation between number of clusters and granularity.

Group-level analysis: We will submit all participant-level data to four clustering analyses using DP-GMM with Variational Inference. Data points (i.e., vectors) will vary by analysis. First, we will include only participant means for IBI, RSA, RR, and PEP (4 features total). Second, we will add participant-level estimates of emotional granularity (5 features total). Third, we will include both participant-level means and standard deviations for IBI, RSA, RR, and PEP (8 features total). Fourth, we will again add participant-level estimates of emotional granularity (9 features total). As described above, data points will be standardized prior to clustering. For each group-level clustering analysis, we will examine the mutual information (MI) between clusters and features, to rank which features are driving the clustering. For analyses where granularity is not included as a feature (i.e., analyses 2 and 4), we will use an independent samples t-test or one-way ANOVA (depending on the number of clusters) to determine whether there are significant differences in granularity between clusters.

q21.value: We will use the standard alpha of .05 for determining if the above-described correlations and t-tests/ANOVAs are significant. We will use two-tailed analyses.

q22.value: Following Hoemann et al (2020, January 14), we will review 30-s bins of ECG data to confirm IBI series values are within acceptable ranges (300-2000ms) and that expected beat-to-beat differences are consistent with normal beats and unlikely to be artifacts. ECG data failing any quality check with will be excluded from analysis. We will likewise exclude 30-s bins of ICG data in which B and X points cannot be detected or that correspond to periods of unusable ECG data.

q23.value: Following signal processing and feature extraction, including corresponding quality checks as outlined above, we will examine the distribution of data across participants and remove participants who no longer have a comparable amount of retained data. Specifically, we will examine the number of periods of seated rest, the total length of seated rest across all periods, and the mean length of seated rest per period.

q25.value:
Research using this same overall data set (though, as clarified in the Sampling Plan section, a different subset of the data) has been published to PsyArXiv as: Hoemann, K., Khan, Z., Feldman, M., Nielson, C., Devlin, M., Dy, J., … Quigley, K. (2020, January 14). Context-aware experience sampling reveals the scale of variation in affective experience. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/cvjb8

Other references cited in this preregistration are:
Ernst, J. M., Litvack, D. A., Lozano, D. L., Cacioppo, J. T., & Berntson, G. G. (1999). Impedance pneumography: Noise as signal in impedance cardiography. Psychophysiology, 36(3), 333-338.

attributes.title: A SCOPING REVIEW ON THE METHODOLOGY OF STUDIES EXAMINING THE SUBSTANCE ABUSE, VIOLENCE AND AIDS (SAVA) SYNDEMIC

q1.value: A Scoping Review on the Methodologies of Studies Examining the Substance Abuse, Violence and HIV/AIDS (SAVA) Syndemic

q3.value: The race to develop and implement interventions that prevent or mitigate the effects of the Substance Abuse, Violence, and AIDS (SAVA) syndemic on health is ongoing. As such, methods that accurately measure disease concentration and interaction of the SAVA syndemic and their effects on health outcomes are crucial.  The purpose of this scoping review is to understand the methodology of studies examining the SAVA syndemic and identify gaps in the existing literature.

q4.value: If a paper is examining the SAVA syndemic, their methodology will include: additive models, latent class analysis, regression based path analytic frameworks, confirmatory factor analysis or growth mixture models, and will also address disease concentration and interactions.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: A scoping review of the literature will be conducted.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: A review of the literature was conducted using a pre-determined search strategy that included index and general terms related to the core concepts of substance abuse, violence, HIV/AIDS and syndemics and followed the protocol of Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR). Seven peer-reviewed databases and grey literature were searched. The seven databases included PubMed, Web of Knowledge, Embase, PsycINFO, Proquest Research Library, CINAHL Plus, Sociological Abstracts. The search strategy was approved by an expert librarian and the senior mentor of the project. We will also look through the references of the relevant articles to ensure we have captured and included all relevant literature in our analysis. Using a pre-established eligibility criteria, a table was generated to collect initial information from different data sources by two coders. Each coder was given the same set of search terms and exact search strategy and was asked to conduct the search exactly the same within each of the databases independently in order to ensure that all articles were captured. After all articles are retrieved, coders will remove duplicates and independently code for a master list of articles. Coders will include the following characteristics on REDCap: title, author, year of publication, study location, study design, study population, sample size, outcomes of interest (outcome variables tested), themes identified, intervention, disease concentration and interaction (if it is mentioned and how it is being measured), level of intervention, and main findings. Inter-coder discrepancies will be addressed by a third adjudicator. There is no inclusion or exclusion criteria in terms of population—any population can be included in the study. Any study that mentions the SAVA syndemic will be included in the analysis. Any comparator or control group will be included in the analysis as long as it is relevant to the themes of the paper. There are no time or study design exclusion criteria.

q13.value: Our target number of studies to be included in the analysis is 45.

question.value:
Variables that will be collected include:
-Title, author, year of publication, study location (country/state), study design (meta-anaysis, systematic review, RCT, Cohort, case control, cross sectional, longitudinal, case reports, case series), study population (race/ethnicity/sexual minorities), sample size (total n), outcomes of interest  (substance abuse, HIV/AIDS, trauma, violence), intervention (methodology), disease concentration (is it mentioned? how is it measured?), disease interaction (is it mentioned? how is it measured?), level of intervention (individual, family, community, systems or microsystem, mesosystem, exosystem, macrosystem, chronosystem) and main findings of the study.
Some variables will be described using medians, all others will be described qualitatively due to the nature of the scoping review. Quality assessment of included studies will not be conducted.

q22.value: There are no time or study design exclusion criteria for our scoping review.

q24.value: We expect that certain populations will be documented more frequently in the literature due to their vulnerability to the effects of the SAVA syndemic. We will document what intervention methods and measures are being used and with what frequency.

attributes.title: Social Media Effects on Personality and Popularity Judgement
attributes.description: Our study is a replication of Scott's (2014) study that analyzes social media with aspects of personality and popularity judgements. Participants are given two female Instagram created profiles and are asked to analyze the profiles and posts. After analyzing, the participants rank the individuals in the profiles on 1-7 scale of approachability, extroversion, trustworthiness, social attractiveness, physical attractiveness, and popularity. The independent variables are amount of likes and whether popular or unpopular. The dependent variable is that rating of the six variables that includes extroversion, approachability, trustworthiness, socially attractive, physically attractive, and popularity.

q1.value: Garrett Boston, Angelise Gorss, Lance Grunert, Kamilla Wielgat

q2.value: The first hypothesis is directional and includes that the higher number of friends on a social media account, the more rated their popularity would be perceived. The second hypothesis would be considered directional and that the popular targets with a higher amount of likes will be rated more extroverted, physically attractive and socially attractive.

q3.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Participants signed up to complete the survey via an online database called SONA. They were also personally recruited and emailed the survey explaining the goals of the study via an online informed consent form. They were told, “To form an impression, you are going to be asked questions that test your memory”. This was used as our cover story. Once the participants had given informed consent, they followed instructions on a computer for completing the survey. Participants were told to view each profile for as long as they needed to form an impression. Once they viewed the first profile, they then viewed three of the photos on that profile more closely, in which likes and comments were showcased for each of the photos. The page then closed and they rated the profiles on each of the six variables. They then viewed the second profile and did the same. After this they were asked three open-ended questions, as well as questions in which demographic information was assessed, such as gender, age, and ethnicity. Participants were given no time limit, but we predicted that the survey would take about 10 minutes to complete. Once they completed the questionnaires, the participants were given an online debriefing and thanked for their participation.

q11.value: Participants will be a convenience sample of undergraduate students at a Liberal Arts college. There will be no compensation for participation in the study. Class credit may be offered by some classes for participation in the study. The sample size is to be roughly 255 undergraduate students.

q12.value: The sample size goal is 255 which is 2.5x the population size of Scott's (2014) study.

q13.value: We will get to 255 participants to be involved in the study therefore, once that occurs, no more data will be accepted.

question.value: First variable is the amount of likes on the Instagram posts either being low or high. The second variable is the rating of either being popular or unpopular based.

The measured variable is the six variables that are rated on a Likert scale of 1-7 that includes approachability, trustworthiness, extroversion, physical attractiveness, social attractiveness, and popularity. Demographics are also measured that includes ethnicity, gender, and age.

Our results will show descriptive statistics for the approachability, extroversion, physical attractiveness, social attractiveness, trustworthiness, and finally the overall popularity of the Facebook posts located in Table 1. The construct with popularity is assessed using all the characteristics of participants rating the posts of either being approachable, trustworthy, extroverted, physical, and social attractiveness with an overall score of popularity. The main effect of the overall popularity will show the higher the ratings are for the variables of the Instagram posts, the higher the overall popularity score will be.  
For the second Construct, the number of likes on the Instagram posts, the higher the popularity will be rated by the participants to examine the main effect of the amount of likes per profile. Participants will analyze the Instagram posts and the amount of likes will result in the participants perceiving the individual in the photo to be popular if the photo is highly liked. The lower liked photo of another profile will be perceived as less popular therefore, the amount of likes on a photo will influence the overall rating of be popular or not. 
The interaction of popularity and amount likes will also be assessed. The predicted results will demonstrate that with the amount of likes and the difference of popularity characteristic ratings between the two profiles, will show that the higher liked photos will result in a higher rating for popularity compared to the lower liked photo between the conditions of popular and unpopular. 
We will use the independent Contrast examining on JAMOVI to give the results using the marginal means and cell means of the 2 X 2 matrix of the independent variables. Also, the use of the ANOVA will be used to see if we reject our null or fail to reject our null hypothesis.

q20.value: For exclusion of data, the participants have to pass whether they have an Instagram account and if they use it Instagram at all. If they don't have an Instagram account or never use Instagram, their data will be excluded. Another exclusion criteria is the amount of the followers on their Instagram has to be reported as well.

q21.value: If data is missing from the initial study, we will determine to exclude the data if they left most of the questions blank or if patterns are seen within the data itself.

q23.value: This whole study is a replication of Scott's (2014) research with Facebook however, we changed ours to Instagram as this is a more susceptible social media application of this current day and will give similar results to those of Facebook.

attributes.title: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life
attributes.description: In this project, we test the hypothesis that emotional granularity (a measure of the precision of an individual’s emotion concepts) is significantly positively correlated with resting respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA; used as an index of parasympathetic activity and proxy measure of efficient allostasis) as measured in daily life. We further investigate the nature of this relationship by characterizing patterns of cardiovascular activity during resting periods and emotional events, including and in comparison with measures of emotional granularity.

q1.value: Investigating the relationship between emotional granularity and cardiovascular physiology in daily life: Correlational analyses

q2.value: Katie Hoemann, Zulqarnain Khan, Karen Quigley, Lisa Feldman Barrett

q3.value: Research suggests that resting respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA) may be positively correlated with emotional granularity, yet a direct comparison has never been performed. Recent studies have also shown that RSA is non-linearly related to indices of mental and physical health, with extreme values of RSA linked to maladaptive psychological and physiological processes. In these analyses, we test the hypothesis that granularity is significantly correlated with resting RSA, and investigate the nature of this relationship.

q4.value:
Across participants, emotional granularity will be positively correlated with resting RSA. However, this relationship may be non-linear, such that extremely high values of resting RSA are also associated with lower emotional granularity.
Within participants (across days), emotional granularity will be positively correlated with resting RSA, such that on days when resting RSA is higher, granularity will also be higher; this relationship may also be non-linear.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
As part of a larger study on affective experience and decision making in daily life, 52 participants completed approximately 14, eight-hour days of ambulatory peripheral physiological monitoring. 

Each day, participants visited the lab and were outfitted with sensors and portable equipment to measure their electrocardiogram (ECG) and impedance cardiogram (ICG) as well as bodily movement and posture (via accelerometers). A custom-built smartphone application initiated an experience sampling prompt any time the interbeat interval (IBI; also called heart period) changed by more than ±167ms over an eight-second period, with these thresholds adjusted per participant to ensure they received a comparable number of prompts per day. Prompts were not generated if participants had moved substantially or shifted posture within the proceeding 30s. At each sampling event, participants were prompted to respond to a series of questions presented in smartphone application, including to freely list and provide intensity ratings for their experienced emotions. 

Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. As part of this survey, participants rated each emotional event on a set of 18 standard emotions.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: To date, only data pertaining to the periods surrounding experience samplings have been analyzed. Peripheral physiological data from periods of seated rest (when no experience sampling prompts were generated) have not yet been pre-processed or analyzed.

question.value:
Sixty-seven participants ranging in age from 18-36 years (55% female; 38.8% White, 3.0% Black, 29.8% Asian, 28.4% other; M = 22.8 years, SD = 4.4 years) were recruited from the greater Boston area through posted advertisements, as well as Northeastern University classrooms and online portals. Eligible participants were non-smoking, fluent English-speakers, and excluded if they had a history of cardiovascular illness or stroke, chronic medical conditions, mental illness, asthma, skin allergies, or very sensitive skin. Eligible participants also confirmed they were not taking any medications known to influence physiological arousal including medications for ADHD, insomnia, anxiety, hypertension, rheumatoid arthritis, epilepsy/seizures, cold/flu, or fever/allergies. Participants received $490 as compensation for completing all parts of the study, plus up to an additional $55 in compliance and task incentives. 

Of the 67 recruited participants, six withdrew and an additional nine were dismissed due to poor compliance. A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). 

Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling distributed across a three- to four-week period (M = 24.9 days, SD = 5.5 days). On each day of experience sampling, participants came into the lab and were instrumented for peripheral physiological recordings. Participants were instructed to continue physiological recordings for eight hours each day, after which they were able to remove and recharge all equipment. Upon completing experience sampling each day, participants automatically received an end-of-day survey, which they used to provide additional details about the prompts they completed throughout the day. Before and after the two-week experience sampling protocol, participants also completed two in-lab sessions. The data from these in-lab sessions are not relevant to the present analyses.

q13.value: A total of 52 participants completed the full protocol (56% female; 38.5% White, 1.9% Black, 38.5% Asian, 21.2% other; M = 22.5 years, SD = 4.4 years). Each participant completed approximately 14 days (M = 14.4, SD = 0.6) of context-aware experience sampling.

question.value:
From the peripheral physiological (ECG and ICG) data, we will isolate periods of seated rest according to the following criteria:
- Participant is included in the final sample
- Data from the given day were not corrupted or (for end of day surveys) reported late
- Participant position is seated and not moving (i.e., no forward acceleration)
- Participant maintains this position for at least 30 seconds
- No experience sampling prompt was generated during the rest period

From these resting periods, we will derive the following measures of cardiovascular activity using 30-s bins:
- Inter-beat interval (IBI; i.e., heart rate [HR], derived from ECG)
- Respiratory sinus arrhythmia (RSA; frequency-based measure of heart rate variability [HRV], derived from ECG)
- Root Mean Square of the Successive Differences (RMSSD; time-based measure of HRV, derived from ECG)
- Respiration rate (RR; derived from ICG [Z0])
ECG and ICG data will be analyzed following the signal processing pipeline outlined in Hoemann et al (2020, January 14) - see Other section for full citation. IBI and RSA will be extracted based on prior literature, as detailed in Hoemann et al (2020, January 14). RMSSD will be derived from IBI following Goedhart et al (2007). RR will be derived from ICG (Z0) following Ernst et al (1999).

From the self-reported experience sampling data, we will analyze the intensity endorsements to 18 standard emotion terms from the end-of-day surveys. For each experience sampling prompt, participants rated the following emotions on a 7-point Likert style scale from 0 ('not at all') to 6 ('very much') : “afraid”, “amused”, “angry”, “bored”, “calm”, “disgusted”, “embarrassed”, “excited”, “frustrated”, “grateful”, “happy”, “neutral”, “proud”, “relieved”, “sad”, “serene”, “surprised”, and “worn out”.

For each period seated rest, we will derive the mean across all 30-s bins, such that we have one measure of IBI, RSA, RMSSD, and RR for each resting period. We will then take the mean across all resting periods in a given day, and across all resting periods for a given participant.

For the experience sampling data, we will derive an index of emotional granularity using intra-class correlations (ICCs) using the 'A-k' method (absolute agreement with averaged raters). We will calculate separate ICCs for ratings of positively-valenced emotion (e.g., happy, calm, grateful) and negatively-valenced emotions (e.g., angry, sad, afraid); we will use the mean of these to represent overall granularity. ICC values will be Fisher transformed and inverted (i.e., multiplied by -1, such that most positive values represent higher granularity). ICCs will be calculated for each participant day, as well as across all data for a given participant.

Analyses will be performed at two levels: participant (across days) and group (across participants). These are separate rather than nested analyses.

Participant-level analysis: We will enter day-level estimates of granularity into a hierarchical linear regression with day-level estimates of resting RSA as the dependent variable, controlling for day-level estimates of resting RR. Resting RR will be entered as the first step in the model, and granularity as the second, to test if granularity explains significant variance in resting RSA above and beyond resting RR. We will run separate models to test linear and quadratic relationships between granularity and resting RSA. We will run the models a second time, with day-level estimates of resting RMSSD, to confirm that the observed relationships hold across both frequency- and time-based measures of HRV.

Group-level analysis: We will enter participant-level estimates of granularity into a hierarchical linear regression with participant-level estimates of resting RSA as the dependent variable, controlling for participant-level estimates of resting RR. Resting RR will be entered as the first step in the model, and granularity as the second, to test if granularity explains significant variance in resting RSA above and beyond resting RR. We will run separate models to test linear and quadratic relationships between granularity and resting RSA. We will run the models a second time, with participant-level estimates of resting RMSSD, to confirm that the observed relationships hold across both frequency- and time-based measures of HRV.

q20.value: To test a quadratic relationship between granularity and resting RSA, while controlling for resting RR, we will transform both the resting RSA and resting RR variables before entering them into the regression model. We will mean-center and square these terms.

q21.value: We will use the change in R^2 from step 1 to 2 in the regression model as a measure of the additional variance explained by granularity. We will use the standard alpha of .05 for determining if the R^2 change value is significant. Because we have directional predictions, we will use a one-tailed test for all analyses.

q22.value: Following Hoemann et al (2020, January 14), we will review 30-s bins of ECG data to confirm IBI series values are within acceptable ranges (300-2000ms) and that expected beat-to-beat differences are consistent with normal beats and unlikely to be artifacts. ECG data failing any quality check with will be excluded from analysis. We will likewise exclude 30-s bins of ICG data that correspond to periods of unusable ECG data.

q23.value: Following signal processing and feature extraction, including corresponding quality checks as outlined above, we will examine the distribution of data across participants and remove participants who no longer have a comparable amount of retained data. Specifically, we will examine the number of periods of seated rest, the total length of seated rest across all periods, and the mean length of seated rest per period.

q25.value:
Research using this same overall data set (though, as clarified in the Sampling Plan section, a different subset of the data) has been published to PsyArXiv as: Hoemann, K., Khan, Z., Feldman, M., Nielson, C., Devlin, M., Dy, J., … Quigley, K. (2020, January 14). Context-aware experience sampling reveals the scale of variation in affective experience. https://doi.org/10.31234/osf.io/cvjb8

Other references cited in this preregistration are:
Ernst, J. M., Litvack, D. A., Lozano, D. L., Cacioppo, J. T., & Berntson, G. G. (1999). Impedance pneumography: Noise as signal in impedance cardiography. Psychophysiology, 36(3), 333-338.
Goedhart, A. D., Van Der Sluis, S., Houtveen, J. H., Willemsen, G., & De Geus, E. J. (2007). Comparison of time and frequency domain measures of RSA in ambulatory recordings. Psychophysiology, 44(2), 203-215.

We will run the models a second time, with day-level estimates of resting RMSSD, to confirm that the observed relationships hold across both frequency- and time-based measures of HRV.

Group-level analysis: We will enter participant-level estimates of granularity into a hierarchical linear regression with participant-level estimates of resting RSA as the dependent variable, controlling for participant-level estimates of resting RR. Resting RR will be entered as the first step in the model, and granularity as the second, to test if granularity explains significant variance in resting RSA above and beyond resting RR. We will run separate models to test linear and quadratic relationships between granularity and resting RSA. We will run the models a second time, with participant-level estimates of resting RMSSD, to confirm that the observed relationships hold across both frequency- and time-based measures of HRV.

summary.value: As the costs of lifestyle-related diseases place increasing strain on public healthcare systems, individuals’ role in disease may be proposed as a healthcare rationing criterion. Literature thus far has largely focused on retrospective responsibility in healthcare. The concept of prospective responsibility in the form of a lifestyle contract warrants further investigation. The responsibilisation in healthcare debate also needs to take into account innovative developments in mobile health technology, such as wearable biometric devices and mobile apps, which may change how we hold others accountable for their lifestyles. Little is known about public attitudes towards lifestyle contracts and the use of mobile health technology to hold people responsible in the context of healthcare. This paper has two components. Firstly, it details empirical findings from a survey of 81 members of the United Kingdom general public on public attitudes towards individual responsibility and rationing healthcare, prospective and retrospective responsibility, and the acceptability of lifestyle contracts in the context of mobile health technology. Secondly, we draw on the empirical findings and propose a model of prospective intention-based lifestyle contracts, which is both more aligned with public intuitions and less ethically objectionable than more traditional, retrospective models of responsibility in healthcare.

attributes.title: Research focus: Uncertainty and conspiracy theories
attributes.description:
Uncertainty and conspiracy theories in times of the corona-crisis. 
This subproject examines the connections between trait/state uncertainty and the belief in conspiracy theories. 
Three thematic blocks are considered. In the first block, the extent to which individual susceptibilities increase uncertainty in relation to corona will be considered. The second block deals with the connection between uncertainty and conspiracy theories. In the third block the risk behaviour is examined in more detail.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Uncertainty and conspiracy theories in ties of the corona crisis - a quantitative representative survey

other.value: We would like to register the questionnaire and as well the pre-test data. For reasons of research ethics, the pretest asked about personal stress during the completion of the questionnaire.

sample.value: The survey will cover 1000 Germans aged 18-69 years. The sample is representative for age, gender and federal state.

analyses.value:
In order to answer the two research questions, the different sub-hypotheses will be tested using different quantitative methods: 
H1.1 - H1.4  Regression /Correlation
H2.1 - H2.4: Regression & Moderation analyses
H3.1 & H3.2: Mediation Analysis

outliers.value: Since we work together with a survey institute in Germany (respondi), all questions in the questionnaire are mandatory. Only questionnaires that are completely filled out will be taken into account. As a quality check, all participants who filled out the questionnaire in under 5 Minutes will be excluded.

dependent.value:
All in all, there are 21 questions with a total of 112 items. This project is a sub project and therefore not all of the variables will be used.
A detailed description of all collected variables can be found in the main folder.

For RQ1 the following variables will be used: 
- state uncertainty
- trust in German government
- trust in German health care politics
- use of alternative media
- conspiracy mentality
- trait uncertainty (due to corona) 

RQ2: 
- trait uncertainty
- state uncertainty
- authoritarianism
- conspiracy mentality
- intolerance of uncertainty
- conspiracy belief


RQ3: 
- trait uncertainty
- conspiracy belief
- behaviour 

further explanations for the two main dependent variables: 

1) conspiracy belief / headlines
This variable is collected from 11 different headlines related to the corona virus. Three of the headlines are conspiracy theories, three are fake news, three of the headlines are real news and two of the headlines are fictitious placebo items. The items were tested using a scale of 5. The end of the scale was 1. fully applicable 2. not applicable at all.
In addition to the headlines there are several items in the questionnaire. The question is how credible the respondents consider the respective headlines to be. Furthermore it is asked whether the respondents would share these headlines, like them on a social network site, think they are true, whether they have seen them before and whether they would like to know more about this headline. 

2) (risk) behavior: self-created
This variable is covered by a multiple answer scale. You can choose here: 1. I bought more supplies than usual. 2. I thought to myself: Now more than ever, I'd rather get sick faster than no bed in the intensive care unit afterwards. 3.  I have kept physical distance from people whom I usually shake hands with. 4.  I cancelled a meeting with friends at home. 5. I doubted the coverage of the "mainstream" media. 6. I forwarded a WhatsApp message where I did not know the sender personally. 7. I disinfected or washed my hands and/or objects (e.g. cell phone) more often. These items are measured using a 5 step scale : the scale sections are: never, rarely, sometimes, often, always. A high scale value therefore means a high level of behaviour in relation to the corona crisis

further information about the other variables: 
1) authoritarianism: validated scala ist used Beierlein, C., Asbrock, F., Kauff, M., & Schmidt, P. (2014). 

2) conspiracy mentality: validated scala is used Bruder, M., Haffke, P., Neave, N., Nouripanah, N., & Imhoff, R. (2013).

3) intolerance of uncertainty: validated scala is used and translated by the author Carleton, R. N., Norton, M. P. J., & Asmundson, G. J. (2007). 

4) use of alternative media: From the Reuters digital news report (Newman et al., 2019)

5) state uncertainty: self-created + 1 item of big five scale:  Rammstedt, B., Kemper, C. J., Klein, M. C., Beierlein, C., & Kovaleva, A. (2012). 

6) trait uncertainty: self-created

conditions.value:
conspiracy belief headlines (as stated above) 
conspiracy theory
1. Corona: A plot to fight overpopulation
2. Corona-virus: Secret plan of the government detected
3. US-special forces use Corona as a
distraction to contract their troops at European airports for a secret invasion.

fake news: 
1. Cocaine helps against the corona virus
2. Toilet paper from China: Contaminated with corona"
3. Anti-Corona: When taking in, chlorine oxide
helps

real news: 
1. Epidemiologists recommend long-term restrictions of public life
2. Because of the pandemic: US president Trump wants to activate war-economy law
3. Italy prolongs curfew

placebo: 
1. Dr. Spitzer: Fighting corona with kale
2. Corona: “China’s attempt to restrict European civil rights

hypothesis.value:
RQ1: To what extent do individual risk factors influence personal uncertainty with regard to corona virus-related news coverage? 
H1.1 People who have a high level of trait uncertainty are more insecure about the corona crisis
H1.2 There is a positive relation between conspiracy mentality and the uncertainty surrounding the corona crisis
H1.3 There is a negative relation between trust in information authorities ( (a) health politics (b) German government ) and the uncertainty regarding the corona crisis
H1.4 There is a positive relation between the use of alternative media and the uncertainty surrounding the corona crisis

RQ2: What influence does uncertainty have on the belief in conspiracy theories?
H2.1 Trait uncertainty about the corona virus, increases susceptibility to conspiracy theories
H2.2 The connection between trait uncertainty and belief in conspiracy theories is moderated by the conspiracy mentality
H2.3 The connection between trait uncertainty and belief in conspiracy theories is moderated by the tendency towards right-wing authoritarianism
H2.4 The connection between trait uncertainty and belief in conspiracy theories is moderated by the intolerance of uncertainty

RQ3: What effect do uncertainty and conspiracy belief have on risk behaviour?
H3.1. The higher the trait uncertainty is, the higher is the degree of behavioural change with regard to the corona virus
H3.2 This relationship is mediated by the conspiracy belief

attributes.title: The effects of bilateral STN-DBS on sleep disorders in Parkinson's disease: a meta analysis
attributes.description:
STN-DBS (subthalamic nucleus-deep brain stimulation) is an effects
treatment in reducing motor symptoms of Parkinson's disease patients.
This study aims to answer following questions:
Whether Bilateral STN-DBS can improve sleep disorders in Parkinson's
diesease patients?
If can, what specific symptoms can bilateral STN-DBS improve?
And how long can the improvement sustained?
Is there any predictive factor that is associated with the sleep improvement?
We aim to pool all the data published can answer aforementioned questions.

attributes.title: Coronavirus: Emotional Consequences of Dishonesty
attributes.description: The aim of this study it to examine the emotional consequences of two types of dishonesty: altruistic dishonesty (for the benefit of others) vs. egoistic dishonesty (for the benefit of self), in the context of the Coronavirus epidemic.
